channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Executions Delayed for Two in India Gang Rape Case
item.description: The Supreme Court in India issued a stay of execution for two of the four men convicted of the gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old student on a bus in 2012.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Passengers and Crew of Missing Plane Scrutinized for Aviation Skills
item.description: The focus of the investigation returned to two people on board with expertise — the pilot and his first officer.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: The home of Fariq Abdul Hamid, 27, the first officer on the missing Malaysia Airlines flight, about 15 miles west of Kuala Lumpur.

item.title: Transgender Models Prosper in Brazil, Where Carnival and Faith Reign
item.description: Transgender models are enjoying success in Brazil, where crossing gender lines is increasingly accepted, but they say that the nation’s conservatism can also create a hostile environment.
item.dc:creator: By TAYLOR BARNES
item.media:credit: Lianne Milton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Felipa Tavares, 26, a transgender model, during a photo shoot in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Syrian Forces Close to Taking Over Long-Held Rebel Town
item.description: Government forces, backed by the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, have spent weeks edging toward Yabrud, a critical transit point for militants, refugees and arms heading in and out of Lebanon.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Sentence Cut for Bin Laden Figure
item.description: A doctor, convicted in Pakistan of treason for helping the C.I.A. track down Osama bin Laden, had 10 years cut from his 33-year sentence.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Investigators in Jet Search Rely on an Imperfect Tool
item.description: Lacking typical ways like radar and radio reports from the crew to track the missing Malaysian plane, searchers are left with an hourly electronic “handshake” between the plane and a satellite.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:description: Relatives of Chinese passengers aboard the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 listened in a hotel in Beijing to a news conference by Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia on Saturday.

item.title: Russian Troops Seize Gas Plant Beyond Crimean Border, Ukraine Says
item.description: The troop advance, Russia’s most provocative since its forces took over Crimea two weeks ago, came one day before Crimea was set to vote on whether to secede from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Russia Vetoes U.N. Resolution on Crimea
item.description: Proposed by the United States, the Security Council measure declaring Sunday’s planned secession vote illegal received one no vote. China abstained.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: China’s Central Bank Allows Its Currency More Volatility
item.description: The bank doubled the amount by which the renminbi would be permitted to rise or fall each day, making it more responsive to market forces.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Paralympics, at Peace as Wars Wind Down
item.description: The reality of the Paralympics’ rise over the past decade could be seen in the biographies of so many of its athletes: former soldiers gravely wounded on far-flung battlefields.
item.dc:creator: By BEN SHPIGEL
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Soule, a veteran United States soldier, in a sit-ski sprint last week at the Paralympics in Russia.

item.title: News Analysis: Israel Reaches Out to the Diaspora
item.description: It feels more comfortable asking for help and more supportive of Jews abroad.
item.dc:creator: By ETHAN BRONNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: In recent years, Beit Shemesh, a city of 80,000 near Jerusalem, has become the scene of conflicts between secular and ultra-Orthodox Israelis. Its population is about evenly split between the two groups.

item.title: Melba Hernández, a Confidante of Castro From First Volley, Is Dead at 92
item.description: Ms. Hernández became one of the first four members of Fidel Castro’s general staff and helped him during the Cuban revolution.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Melba Hernández and Fidel Castro at the 1999 burial of a fellow revolutionary, Jesus Montane, whom she married.

item.title: Malaysia Officials Open Criminal Inquiry Into Missing Jet
item.description: Prime Minister Najib Razak said in a news conference that data indicated that someone took action to change the course of the plane, which traveled for seven hours after it lost contact with ground control.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Malaysian and Japanese crews searched for the missing Malaysian flight over the waters of the South China Sea on Saturday.

item.title: Out of Office, Sarkozy Is Still Front and Center
item.description: Accusations of Libyan campaign donations and secret recordings keep the former French president in the headlines.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Expectations that Nicolas Sarkozy will try to regain the French presidency have only served to heighten the drama around him, which lately involves court cases and judicial investigations.

item.title: Thousands March in Moscow to Protest Crimea Vote
item.description: Tens of thousands have gathered in downtown Moscow in the largest anti-government demonstration since 2012, protesting against Sunday’s Kremlin-backed referendum in Crimea on whether to break away from Ukraine and merge with Russia.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Protesters in Moscow carried Ukrainian and Russian flags at a rally on Saturday against recent Russia's move on Crimea.

item.title: Foes of America in Russia Crave Rupture in Ties
item.description: As the United States threatens sanctions against Russia, influential members of President Putin’s inner circle view isolation from the West as a good thing.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Mikhail Klimentyev/RIA Novosti Kremlin, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with his national security advisers in Sochi, Russia, on Thursday.

item.title: For Crimea, Secession Is Only as Good as Recognition
item.description: Crimean and Russian officials cite the independence of Kosovo to justify secession, but even Kosovo has struggled to gain international legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Economic View: Crimea Through a Game-Theory Lens
item.description: As applied to political crises, economic concepts suggest that negotiated settlements may become elusive.
item.dc:creator: By TYLER COWEN
item.media:description: In 1997, soldiers prepared to destroy a missile housed at a former Soviet base in Ukraine. After the Soviet Union’s breakup, Ukraine gave up its portion of the old Soviet nuclear arsenal.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Saudi’s Lonely, Costly Bid for Sunni-Shiite Equality
item.description: Mikhlif al-Shammari has been jailed and even shot by his own son because he holds a very unusual conviction in his deeply conservative country: that Shiites should be treated equally.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:description: ‘I’m ready to pay with my life for my beliefs.’ MIKHLIF AL-SHAMMARI

item.title: Indian Court Stays Hanging of 2 Rape Case Convicts
item.description: India's top court on Saturday temporarily stayed the hanging of two of the four men convicted for the 2012 gang rape and murder of a young woman on a bus in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: India Expands Its Efforts in Search for Missing Jet
item.description: The country’s forces are intensifying their search in the Andaman Sea, which New Delhi has been eager to show it is able to police militarily.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: India's Andaman and Nicobar Islands. The Indian Navy is conducting a vast operation to find Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: 2 Choices in Crimea Referendum, but Neither Is ‘No’
item.description: The ballot referendum will present two options for the region: joining Russia or increasing its autonomy within the Ukrainian government.
item.dc:creator: By NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crimeans look at signs in support of joining Russia.

item.title: Malaysian Prime Minister’s Statement on Flight 370 Investigation
item.description: The text of Prime Minister Najib Razak’s statement Saturday.

item.title: India Ink: Families of Indians on Missing Flight Plead for Information
item.description: They say they have had very little official information about the developments in the search for the Malaysia Airlines jetliner.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: K.S. Narendran, center, husband of Chandrika Sharma, a passenger in the missing Malaysia Airlines aircraft, speaking to journalists in Chennai, India, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Navy Strategists Have a Long History of Finding the Lost
item.description: The Office of Naval Intelligence has refined some of the most creative techniques that have been used to find sunken ships, spent warheads and downed pilots.
item.dc:creator: By BENEDICT CAREY
item.media:description: The submarine Scorpion was found by a Navy team after it sank in the North Atlantic in 1968.
